Award.AwardTitle: II-New: TeraNova: An Integrated Testbed for True Terahertz Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless data traffic has surged in recent years due to a change in the way society today creates, shares, and consumes information. Accompanying this change is an increasing demand for faster, more ubiquitous wireless communication networks. As a result, wireless Terabit-per-second (Tbps) links are expected to become a necessity within the next five to ten years. Terahertz (THz)-band (0.1 to 10 THz) communication is envisioned as a key technology to meet this demand. For many years, the lack of compact and efficient ways to generate and detect THz-band signals limited the feasibility of such communication systems. Ongoing advances in THz generation and detection schemes are making sources and detectors more readily available, but no platform currently exists to experimentally demonstrate wireless communication at true THz frequencies. The objective of this TeraNova project is to develop the first integrated testbed specific to ultra-broadband communication networks at true terahertz frequencies (i.e., 1 THz and above).

The main components of the testbed are as follows. In transmission, a Schottky-diode-based frequency multiplier and amplifier is used to generate a THz carrier signal in the first absorption-defined transmission window above 1 THz, i.e., between 1 and 1.075 THz. A sub-harmonic mixer based on the same technology is used to modulate the THz carrier signal with the broadband signal to be transmitted, which is generated by means of a broadband arbitrary-waveform generator. The waveform generator has two parallel channels with an analog bandwidth of 32 Gigahertz (GHz) per channel and high sampling rate with 8-bit resolution. Each waveform can be defined allowing precise control of baseband signals. In reception, the same setup is used to down-convert the modulated THz signal and recover the transmitted symbols. The downconverted signal is displayed and stored, prior to demodulation and signal processing, by means of a high performance digital oscilloscope, which has up to 63 GHz of analog bandwidth for one channel or 33 GHz per channel with two channels. The described TeraNova testbed enables new CISE-related research opportunities, including development and validation of (i) accurate THz channel models, (ii) ultra-broadband modulation and demodulation techniques, and (iii) ultra-massive MIMO communication schemes, among others. In addition, the TeraNova testbed serves as a unique platform to test and benchmark novel plasmonic THz devices for communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless data traffic has surged in recent years due to a change in the way today?s society creates, shares, and consumes information. Accompanying this change has been an extraordinary growth both in the number of wirelessly interconnected devices as well as on the data rates at which these devices communicate. Following the current trend, wireless Terabit-per-second (Tbps, a trillion of bits per second) links are expected to become a necessity within the next five years. However, the limited available resources in the microwave frequency spectrum motivates the exploration of higher frequency bands for communication. Even the recently adopted millimeter-wave communication systems, which play a fundamental role in 5G systems, are challenged to support Tbps, mainly due to the lack of wide-enough consecutive spectral bandwidths.

Moving further up in the spectrum, the Terahertz (THz) band (from 100 GHz up to 10 THz) is envisioned as a key player in the future of wireless communication networks. For many years, the lack of compact and efficient ways to generate and detect as well as to modulate and demodulate THz signals limited the feasibility of THz communication networks. However, major recent advancements in the fields of THz electronic, photonic and plasmonic device technologies are finally closing the THz gap. In parallel to the development of such technologies, there is a need to study the propagation of THz signals and to develop new communication techniques tailored to the capabilities of THz devices and peculiarities of the THz channel. For many years, these works were mainly theoretical, due to the lack of an experimental platform to test wireless communication systems in the THz band.

The objective of this project has been to develop the first integrated testbed specific to ultra-broadband communication networks at true terahertz frequencies (i.e., 1 THz and above). The main components of the testbed are as follows. In transmission, a state-of-the-art Schottky-diode-based frequency multiplier and amplifier is used to generate a THz carrier signal in the first absorption-defined transmission window above 1 THz, i.e., between 1 and 1.075 THz. A sub-harmonic mixer based on the same technology is used to modulate the THz carrier signal with the broadband signal to be transmitted, which is generated by means of an ultra-broadband arbitrary-waveform generator with more than 32 GHz bandwidth. In reception, the same setup is used to down-convert the modulated THz signal and recover the transmitted symbols. The downconverted signal is displayed and stored, prior to demodulation and signal processing, by means of a high-performance digital oscilloscope with 63 GHz of bandwidth.

By utilizing this testbed, we have been able to experimentally characterize, for the first time, the wireless channel at true THz frequencies, i.e., between 1 and 1.075 THz, in the time and frequency domains. Moreover, beyond channel measurements, we have designed, implemented and experimentally tested for the first time ever a myriad of modulation schemes at true THz frequencies, with which we have demonstrated error-free multi-Gbps links over short distances. These results serve as the benchmark for new ultra-broadband communication techniques that need to be developed to increase both the data rate and the communication distance. In addition, through collaboration with other research groups, we have extended the frequency of operation of our testbed to other THz frequency bands. Beyond our own technical work, we have shared the collected data sets for the channel and the physical layer traces with the broader research community, we have contributed to the US Federal Communications Commission first attempts at the regularization of the THz band, and we have participated in the IEEE standardization efforts for the THz communications. It is our group intent to not only maintain but enhance the platform which we open to the entire wireless research community.
